D.text:
I feel convinced that his conduct has not been guilty: I believe that
people are almost always better than their neighbors think they are,

Mr. Lydgate would understand that if his friends hear a calumny about
him their first wish must be to justify him.  What do we live for, if
it is not to make life less difficult to each other?  I cann
all the more because he was really her best friend.
Oh, how cruel!

And would you not
like to be the one person who believed in that man's innocence, if the
rest of the world belied him?  Besides, there is a man's character
beforehand to speak for him.
Then it may be rescued and healed,

I should not be
afraid of asking Mr. Lydgate to tell me the truth, that I might help
him.  Why should I be afraid?  Now that I am not to have the land,
James, I might do as Mr. Bulstrode proposed, and
As if I wanted a husband!

I only want not to have my
feelings checked at every turn.

Of course I submitted to him, because it was my duty; it was my
feeling for him,

haunted
her like a passion,

They all owed their significance to her marriage and its
troubles—but no; there were two occasions in which the image of

else.

It was not the change of emaciation, but that effect which
even young faces will very soon show from the persistent presence of
resentment and despondency.
I have wished very much to see you for a long while, Mr. Lydgate,

but I put off

Hospital.  I know that the advantage of keeping the management of it
separate from that of the Infirmary depends on y
Not because there is no one to believe in you?

I know the unhappy
mistakes about you.  I knew them from the first moment to be mistakes.
You have never done anything vile.  You would not do anything
dishonorable.
I beseech you to tell me how everything was,
I am sure that the truth would clear you.
Tell me, pray,

then we can
consult together.  It is wicked to let people think evil of any one
falsely, when it can be hindered.
Do trust me,

I will not repeat anything without your
leave.  But at the very least, I could say that you have made all the

guilty.  Mr. Farebrother
Oh, it is hard!

I understand the difficulty there is
in your vindicating yourself.  And that all this should have come to

Suppose,

It would be quite worth my while,

Only
think.  I am very uncomfortable with my money, because they tell me I

have too much.  I don't know what to do.  I have seve
I think you see now that you spoke too scrupulously,

The hospital would be one good; and making your
life quite whole and well again would be another.

Had he that sorrow
too?

I know, I know—you could not give her pain, if you were not obliged
to do it,
But when she saw the good that might come of staying—
May I go and see her?

Would she accept my

how well she knew that there might be
invisible barriers to speech between husband and wife.  This was a

And if Mrs. Lydgate knew that there were friends who would believe in

You need not decide immediately,

A few days hence
it will be early enough for me to send my answer to Mr. Bulstrode.
It hurts me very much to hear you speak so hopelessly,

It would be a happiness to your friends, who believe in your future,
in your power to do great things, if you would let them save you from
that.  Think how much money I have; it would be like taking a
Now that is not brave,
to give up the fight."
Mr. Farebrother will believe—others will believe,

I
can say of you what will make it stupidity to suppose that you would be

Yes, I will.  I remember how pretty she is,

I hope she will
like me.

any other name if it did but imply that he granted her request.

I shall talk to her about her husband,

Is Mrs. Lydgate at home?
Say that I am Mrs. Casaubon,

Excuse me, Mrs. Lydgate, the servant did not know that you were here.
I called to deliver an important letter for Mr. Lydgate, which I wished
to put into your own hands.
Drive on to Freshitt Hall,

And she would
carry out the purpose with which she had started in the morning, of

Yes, dear, a great many things have happened,
Oh, all the troubles of all people on the face of the earth,
her little world was in ruins,
That house was never dull, Mr. Farebrother, like another White of Selborne, having continually something new to tell of his inarticulate guests and proteges, whom he was teaching the boys not t
I must go; I have overtired myself.
Oh, I did love him!

Here, with the nearness of an answering smile, here within the

no, a living man towards whom there could not yet

Why had he come obtruding his life into hers, hers that

regard and his lip-born words to her who had nothing paltry to give in
e
For now the thoughts came thickly.
Was she alone in that scene?  Was it her event only?

And what sort of crisis might not this be in three lives whose contact
with hers laid an obligation on her as if they had been suppliants
bearing the sacred branch?  The objects of her rescue were not

What should I do—how should I act now, this very day,
if I could clutch my own pain, and compel it to silence, and think of
those three?

She was a part of that
involuntary, palpitating life, and could neither look out on it from

complaining.
Don't be alarmed, Tantripp,

I have slept; I
am not ill.  I shall be glad of a cup of coffee as soon as possible.
And I want you to bring me my new dress; and most likely I shall want
my new bonnet to-day.
The fire will do, my good Tan,

get me the
coffee.
For the resolve was not easy.
Do you think that Mrs. Lydgate can receive me this morning?

It was plain that Lydgate, as Dorothea had expected, knew nothing about
the circumstances of her yesterday's visit; nay, he appeared to imagine
that she had carried it out according to her intention.

It is I who have most to thank for, since
you have let me take that place.  You <emph rend="italics">have</emph> consented?

But Dorothea had counted a little too much on her own
strength:
all her effort was required to keep back tears.

I had an errand yesterday which I did not finish; that is why I am

The day before yesterday,

when I had asked him to

The fragile creature who
was crying close to her—there might still be time to rescue her from

We were talking about your husband,

I thought his looks were sadly changed with suffering the

i
It was himself he blamed for not speaking,

What he

Marriage is so unlike everything else.  There is

I know, I know that the feeling
may be very dear—it has taken hold of us unawares—it is so hard, it

It was a tumult in which the terrible strain of the night and morning

she cared for
Rosamond without struggle now,
No, he cannot reproach you any more.
You are not sorry that I came this morning?

But better days will come.  Your husband will be rightly valued.  And
he depends on you for comfort.  He loves you best.  The worst loss
would be to lose that—and you have not lost it,
Perhaps there was a faint taste of jealousy in the question.
No, indeed!  How could you imagine it?
Oh, no!  I am strong: I need the walk,

Mrs. Lydgate and I have chatted a great deal,
and it is time for me to go.  I have always been accused of being
immoderate and saying too much.

To-day was to be spent quite differently.  What

Oh dear!  oh dear!
Do sit down,

Am I wanted
for anything?  I shall be so glad if I can do anything.

Could she

Yes, I will see him,
Pray tell him to come.
What else was there to be done?

If I

I wanted to see you,
Yes—yes—I know,
You acted as I should have expected you to act,

you,
Nothing could have changed me but—

but thinking that
you were different—not so good as I had believed you to be.
I don't doubt you any longer,
See how dark the clouds have become, and how the trees are tossed,

But I have felt worse—it was worse to think ill—

I would

No—don't say that—your life need not be maimed,
Some time—we might,

at that moment debate was mute within her.  And it

Oh, I cannot bear it—my heart will break,
I don't mind about poverty—I hate my wealth.

We could live quite well on my
own fortune—it is too much—seven hundred a-year—I want so little—no
new clothes—and I will learn what everything costs.
O Kitty, I am delighted to see you!

I almost thought you would
not come to me.
On the contrary, dear,

I never could do anything that
I liked.  I have never carried out any plan yet.
Dear Celia,

if you don't ever
see me, it will not be my fault.
I am going to London,
Bless you, Kitty,

Take comfort:
perhaps James will forgive me some time.
It is quite true that I might be a wiser person, Celia,

and that I might have done something better, if I had been
better.  But this is what I am going to do.  I have promised to marry
Mr. Ladislaw; and I am going to marry him.
I hope so.  I am very fond of him.
I dare say not,

If you
knew how it came about, it would not seem wonderful to you.
No, dear, you would have to feel with me, else you would never know.

They were bound to each other by a
love stronger than any impulses which could have marred it.

JC.text: Exactly
But, Dorothea,

you can't undertake to manage
a man's life for him in that way.  Lydgate must know—at least he will
soon come to know how he stands.  If he can clear himself, he will.  He
must act for himself.

Surely, a woman is bound to be cautious and listen to those who know
the world better than she does.

Whatever you do in the end, Dorothea, you should really keep
back at present, and not volunteer any meddling with this Bulstrode
business.  We don't know yet what may turn up.  You must agree with
me?
interfering in this Bulstrode business,

And perhaps there had been some pleasure in pointing Mr.

What is the matter?

Not another gamekeeper shot, I
hope?  It's what I should expect, when a fellow like Trapping Bass is
let off so easily.
For God's sake let us hear what it is!
Exactly,
But <emph rend="italics">what</emph> is worse?
When did you learn this?

It would have been better if I had called him out and shot him a year
ago,

That is not so very easy for a man of any dignity—with any sense of
right—when the affair happens to be in his own family,

It is perfectly scandalous.
If Ladislaw had had a spark of honor he would have gone out of the

not surprised.  The day after Casau
Yes,

it is rather a pity
you formed that high opinion of him.  We are indebted to that for his

a woman like Dorothea degrading herself

No—excuse me—I shall not,

I
cannot bear to see her again; it is too painful.  It hurts me too much

Yes, I do,

I think that Dorothea commits a
wrong action in marrying Ladislaw.
I don't know what you mean by wrong, Cadwallader,

He's not a man we can take into the family.  At least, I
must speak for myself,

I suppose others will find his society too pleasant to

Oh, of course, if you like,

That is
to say, if it is not to meet anybody else.
What, now, directly?
Remember, Celia, I cannot see her,

What is the use of saying that?—however, I'm going to the stables.
I'll tell Briggs to bring the carriage round.
Good heavens, Celia!

Such being the bent of Celia's heart, it was inevitable that Sir James

Where women love each other, men learn to smother their mutual

they were on a footing of

drawn me in uncommonly with r

somebody who will manage your

Well, my dear!
Well, you're all here, you know,
The Bill, eh? ah!

Thrown out, you know, eh?  The Lords are going too far,

Gamekeeper?  No. Let us go in; I can tell you all in the house, you
know,

when you are

Well, it's a very trying thing, you know,

Well, you know, Chettam, I couldn't help Casaubon's will: it was a

Dorothea is going to be married again, you know,
Yes; to Ladislaw,
Yesterday,

I went to Lowick.  Dorothea

You wanted what was impossible, you know, Chettam,

You wanted him shipped off.  I told you Ladislaw was not to be done as

I pointed everything out to her,

I
mean the poverty, and abandoning her position.  I said, 'My dear, you

y
In three weeks, you know,

I'll go with you,

No, no, no,

Dorothea

My dear sir, it
is not for me to dictate to you, but for my part I would let that

Celia.text: Now, Dodo, do listen to what James says,

else you will
be getting into a scrape.  You always did, and you always will, when
you set about doing as you please.  And I think it is a mercy now after
all that you have got James to think for you.
Now, really, Dodo,

you <emph rend="italics">are</emph> contradictory: first one thing and then another.  You
used to submit to Mr. Casaubon quite shamefully: I think you would have
given up ever coming to see me if he h

Then why can't you think it your duty to submit a little to what James
wishes?

Because he only wishes what is for your own good.  And, of course, men
know best about everything, except what women know better.
Well, I mean about babies and those things,

I
should not give up to James when I knew he was wrong, as you used to do
to Mr. Casaubon.
Dodo, how very bright your eyes are!

And you don't see anything you look at, Arthur
or anything.  You are going to do something uncomfortable, I know.  Is
it all about Mr. Lydgate, or has something else happened?
I wonder what,
Dear me, Dodo, are you going to have a scheme for them?
Lady
Mrs.,

Viscount—and his lordship's little tooth coming through!  He might

Oh, I only meant about Arthur's little tooth,
But see, here is my uncle coming.
It must be about Dodo,
Really, James, that would have been very disagreeable,
It is very dreadful of Dodo, though,

Do
you mean that Dodo is going to be married directly, uncle?
You will, James—won't you?

Do you mind about my
having the carriage to go to Lowick, James?
Yes, it is very important,
Not if she gave up marrying?

How could any one understand Dodo so well
as Celia did or love her so tenderly?
I have not brought Arthur, because I was in a hurry,
You know, Dodo, it is very bad,

You have
disappointed us all so.  And I can't think that it ever <emph rend="italics">will</emph> be—you
never can go and live in that way.  And then there are all your plans!
You never can have thoug
Because you always wanted things that wouldn't do. But other plans would have come. And how can you marry Mr. Ladislaw, that we none of us ever thought you could m
Well, it is very serious, Dodo,

How will you live? and you will go away among queer people.  And I

Yes, it will,

How can I come to you or have you with me when James
can't bear it?—that is because he thinks it is not right—he thinks

loving you

How can you always live in a street?  And you will be so poor.  I

But it would be much better if you would not be married,

then there would be
nothing uncomfortable.  And you would not do what nobody thought you
could do.  James always said you ought to be a queen; but this is not
at all being like a queen.  You know what
Is he very fond of you, Dodo?
That is nice,

Only I would rather you had such a
sort of husband as James is, with a place very near, that I could drive
to.
I cannot think how it all came about.
Can't you tell me?

Dorothea has a little boy.  And you will not let me go and see her.
And I am sure she wants to see me.  And she will not know what to do
with the baby—she will do wrong things with it.  And they thoug

wish?  I will do anything you like.  I will take you to town to-morrow

Lyd.text:
Everything that bad happened to him there seemed a
mere preparation for this hateful fatality, which had come as a blight
on his honorable ambition, and must make even people who had only
vulgar stand

How was he to live on without vindicating himself among people who
suspected him of baseness?  How could he go silently away from
Middlemarch as if he were retreating before a just condemnation?  And

He was afraid of some betrayal in my
hearing: all he wanted was to bind me to him by a strong obligation:
that was why he passed on a sudden from hardness to liberality.  And he
may have tampered with

There was a benumbing cruelty in his position.  Even if he renounced

But then came the question whether he should have acted in precisely

continued alive and susceptible of further treatment when he

If he had been
independent, this matter of a patient's treatment and the distinct rule
that he must do or see done that which he believed best for the life
committed to him, would have been the point

The reasons were too plain now.
The general black-balling had begun.

He would not retreat before calumny, as if he
submitted to it.  He would face it to the utmost, and no act of his
should show that he was afraid.  It belonged to the generosity as well
as defiant forc
How would Rosamond take it all?
Some little nervous shock,
There is often something poisonous in the air of public rooms,

strengt
This is Chichely's scratch.  What is he writing to you about?

Certainly Rosamond in this
case had equal reason to complain of reserve and want of confidence on

I am a fool.  Haven't I given up expecting anything?  I
have married care, not help.
Rosamond, have you heard anything that distresses you?
What have you heard?
That people think me disgraced?
Yes,

If she has any trust in me—any
notion of what I am, she ought to speak now and say that she does not
believe I have deserved disgrace.

Even this trouble, like the rest, she seemed
to regard as if it were hers alone.  He was always to her a being
apart, doing what she objected to.

the occasion must not be lost.  If he could bring

Well?

Instead of that critical outpouring for
which he had prepared himself with effort, here was the old round to be

The beginning of mutual understanding and resolve seemed as far off as
ever; nay, it seemed blocked out by the sense of unsuccessful effort.

You want to decide whether you should give a generous support to the

I cannot conscientiously advise you to do it
in dependence on any activity of mine.  I may be obliged to leave the

Thank you.
I don't want,

to bear hard on Bulstrode, who has lent me
money of which I was in need—though I would rather have gone without

for a defence against ready accusers.
It has come to my knowledge since,

that Hawley sent some
one to examine the housekeeper at Stone Court, and she said that she

deal of brandy.  But that would not hav
Yes,

I had some ambition.  I meant everything to be
different with me.  I thought I had more strength and mastery.  But the
most terrible obstacles are such as nobody can see except oneself.
That might do if I had my old trust in myself,

Nothing galls me more than the notion of turning round
and running away before this slander, leaving it unchecked behind me.

which d

grave-eyed earnestness with which Dorothea said all this was
irresistible—blent into an adorable whole with her ready understanding

You have the goodness as well as the
money to do all that; if it could be done,
But—

Why should I not tell you?—you know what sort of bond marriage is.
You will understand everything.

It is impossible for me now to do anything—to take any step without

She would not see it,

And, indeed, I have lost
all spirit about carrying on my life here.

The fact is, this trouble has come
upon her confusedly.  We have not been able to speak to each other

Well, Rosy,

her married life had fulfilled none

Is there anything the matter, papa?
Is it anything about Tertius?
No, papa,

He had always before been disposed to
find the utmost fault with Lydgate.

All the shame seemed to be there.  And she had
innocently married this man with the belief that he and his family were

What had he really done—how had he really acted?  She did
not know.  Why had he not told her everything?  He did not speak to her
on the subject, and of course she could not speak to him.
Yes,
Everything, I suppose.  Papa told me.

Whatever was to be said on the subject she expected to come from

Whatever might be the truth about all
this misery, there was one dread which asserted itself.
Surely, Tertius—

Surely now at last you have given up the idea of staying in

Yes, child, I
don't mind a hundred or two.  I can see the end of that.

If you like,

this detail not
immediately affecting her

Rosamond dared not say no.  She dared not with a tone of her voice

Rosamond could not avoid
meeting her glance, could not avoid putting her small hand into

Of course Mrs.
Casaubon had the facts in her mind, but she was not going to speak of

I know you have been very good.  I shall like to hear anything you

Thank you: you are very kind.
What was the use of thinking about behavior after this crying?
Tertius is so angry and impatient if I say anything,

He ought
not to wonder that I object to speak to him on painful subjects.
You are thinking what is not true,
When you came in yesterday—it was not as you thought,

He was telling me how he loved another woman, that I might know he

And now I think he hates me because—because you

No, you have been very good to me,

Tertius did not find fault with me, then?

very beautiful.  If you go to talk to her so often, you will be more

so often.
I think she has,

How heavy

Poor Rosamond's vagrant fancy had come back terribly

MrsV.text:
Oh, my dear, have you heard
nothing?  It won't be long before it reaches you.

Lad.text:
meeting Dorothea's eyes with a new
lightning in them, seemed changing to marble.
Don't touch me!

It seemed as impossible to bear the fatality she had
drawn down on him without venting his fury as it would be to a panther
to bear the javelin-wound without springing and biting.  And yet—how
could h
Go after her!

Do you
think she would turn to look at me, or value any word I ever uttered to
her again at more than a dirty feather?—Explain!  How can a man
explain at the expense of a woman?

Do you suppose she would like me better for sacrificing you?  She is
not a woman to be flattered because I made myself despicable—to
believe that I must be true to her because I was a dastard to you.

I had no hope before—not much—of anything better to come.  But I had
one certainty—that she believed in me.  Whatever people had said or
done about me, she believed in me.—That's gone!  She'll never a

Explain!  Tell a man to explain how he dropped into hell!  Explain my

preference for breathing.  No ot

that his life might come to be enslaved by this helpless

Shall I
come in and see Lydgate this evening?

Did not Mrs. Lydgate tell you that I
came this morning?
Not seriously, I hope,

I travelled all night and got to the White Hart at eight o'clock this
morning. I have been shutting myself up and resting,
Yes,

I shall be fortunate if gossip does
not make me the most disreputable person in the whole affair.  I should

merely for the

fair R

Nothing had done instead—not the opera, or the converse of zealous

But he had found that humdrum

he must go to her again; the

What Rosamond had
written to him would probably deepen the painful impressions of the

There might still
remain in her mind a changed association with him which made an

Until that wretched yesterday—except the moment of

as in a world apart
I am so grateful to you for seeing me.

I fear you think me foolish and perhaps wrong for coming back so soon.
I have been punished for my impatience.  You know—every one knows
now—a painful story about my parentage.  I knew of it before I
But the affair is matter of gossip now,

I wished
you to know that something connected with it—something which happened

You know that it must be altogether painful to me.

I did not choose to accept an income from such a source.  I was sure
that you would not think well of me if I did so,

Why
should he mind saying anything of that sort to her now?  She knew that

I felt that

I did not believe that you would let any circumstance of my birth
create a prejudice in you against me, though it was sure to do so in
others,
You are sure to believe me better than I am in everything but one,

I
mean, in my truth to you.  When I thought you doubted of that, I didn't
care about anything that was left.  I thought it was all over with me,
and there was nothing to try for—only things to endure.
He was not much afraid of anything that she might feel now.
You have never felt the sort of misery I felt,

the misery
of knowing that you must despise me.

We may at least have the comfort of speaking to each other without

may think of me as one on the brink of the grave.
There is no hope for me,

Even if you loved me as well as
I love you—even if I were everything to you—I shall most likely
always be very poor: on a sober calculation, one can count on nothing
but a creeping lot.  It is impossi
It is impossible!
It is as fatal as a murder or any other horror that divides people,

it is more intolerable—to have our life maimed by
petty accidents.
Yes, it must,

It is cruel of you to speak in
that way—as if there were any comfort.  You may see beyond the misery

as if it were a trifle, to spe
When?

What is the use of counting on any
success of mine?  It is a mere toss up whether I shall ever do more

and a mouthpiece.  I can
Good-by.

LC.text:
James's title is worth far more
than any new earldom.  I never wished his father to be anything else
than Sir James.
I heard her say the same thing myself,

cannot be said to have descended below her rank.  It is difficult to

M.text:
his eyebrows made their pathetic angle, and there was a tender gravity
in his voice: these things had been signs to her when she was Letty's
age.
Not a sad while, father—I mean to be merry,

I have been single and merry for four-and-twenty years and more: I
suppose it will not be quite as long again as that.
If you are contented with Fred?

Now, father, you did praise him last Wednesday.  You said he had an
uncommon notion of stock, and a good eye for things.
Yes, I put it all down, and the date, anno Domini, and everything,
No, indeed, father.  I don't love him because he is a fine match.

Oh, dear, because I have always loved him.  I should never like
scolding any one else so well; and that is a point to be thought of in
a husband.
My feelings have not changed, father,

I shall be
constant to Fred as long as he is constant to me.  I don't think either
of us could spare the other, or like any one else better, however much
we might admire them.  It would make too great
How can that ever be, father?
Oh, Fred would be so happy!  It is too good to believe.
Perhaps it is too much, father,
There would be no happiness in bringing you any fresh trouble.
Oh, you dear good father!

I wonder if any other girl thinks her father the best man in the
world!
Impossible,

husbands are
an inferior class of men, who require keeping in order.
What fine clothes you wear, you extravagant youth!

You are
not learning economy.

How very droll you will look!—like a gentleman in an old
fashion-book.
Two years! be reasonable, Fred,

Don't
encourage flattering expectations.

I have heard a story of a young gentleman who once encouraged
flattering expectations, and they did him harm.

Should you call it bad news to be told that you were to live at Stone
Court, and manage the farm, and be remarkably prudent, and save money
every year till all the stock and furniture were your own, a

That is what my father has just told me of as what may happen, and he
never talks nonsense,

till it rather hurt her; but she would
not complain.

Not so fast, sir; how do you know that I would not rather defer our
marriage for some years?  That would leave you time to misbehave, and
then if I liked some one else better, I should have an excuse

It is all true, Fred, and I am happy because of it—because I love you
best,
that would be too great a trial to your mother.

F.text: Now that is too bad, Mary,

Just look at the edges of
these coat-cuffs! It is only by dint of good brushing that I look
respectable.  I am saving up three suits—one for a wedding-suit.
Oh no, they will keep two years.

Why not?  One lives on them better than on unflattering ones.  If we
can't be married in two years, the truth will be quite bad enough when
it comes.

Mary, if you've got something discouraging to tell me, I shall bolt; I
shall go into the house to Mr. Garth.  I am out of spirits.  My father
is so cut up—home is not like itself.  I can't bear any mo
You don't mean anything except nonsense, Mary?

Oh, I could be a tremendously good fellow then, Mary, and we could be
married directly.

Tell me
seriously that all this is true, and that you are happy because of
it—because you love me best.

When we were first engaged, with the umbrella-ring, Mary, you used
to—
He was ten times worthier of you than I was,

and for that
reason he could do better without me.  But you—I shudder to think what
you would have been—a curate in debt for horse-hire and cambric

descriptions.D: behind. Dorothea's impetuous generosity, which would have leaped at once to the vindication of Lydgate from the suspicion of having accepted money as a bribe, underwent a melancholy check when she came to consider all the circumstances of the case by the light of Mr. Farebrother's experience. It is a delicate matter to touch, he said. How can we begin to inquire into it? It must be either publicly by setting the magistrate and coroner to work, or privately by questioning Lydgate. As to the first
descriptions.Celia: with this Bulstrode business. We don't know yet what may turn up. You must agree with me? he ended, looking at Mr. Farebrother. I do think it would be better to wait, said the latter. Yes, yes, my dear, said Mr. Brooke, not quite knowing at what point the discussion had arrived, but coming up to it with a contribution which was generally appropriate. It is easy to go too far, you know. You must not let your ideas run away with you. And as to being in a hurry to put money into schemes—it won't do
descriptions.B: with her native directness, What is it that you have in your mind? she found herself anxious to get away before she had heard anything more explicit. She began to have an agitating certainty that the misfortune was something more than the mere loss of money, being keenly sensitive to the fact that Selina now, just as Mrs. Hackbutt had done before, avoided noticing what she said about her husband, as they would have avoided noticing a personal blemish. She said good-by with nervous haste, and tol
descriptions.Lyd: n know better. Dorothea laughed and forgot her tears. Well, I mean about babies and those things, explained Celia. I should not give up to James when I knew he was wrong, as you used to do to Mr. Casaubon. CHAPTER LXXIII. Pity the laden one; this wandering woe May visit you and me. When Lydgate had allayed Mrs. Bulstrode's anxiety by telling her that her husband had been seized with faintness at the meeting, but that he trusted soon to see him better and would call again the next day, unless she
descriptions.Lad: ination of a certainty which filled up all outlines, something which made her pause, motionless, without self-possession enough to speak. Seated with his back towards her on a sofa which stood against the wall on a line with the door by which she had entered, she saw Will Ladislaw: close by him and turned towards him with a flushed tearfulness which gave a new brilliancy to her face sat Rosamond, her bonnet hanging back, while Will leaning towards her clasped both her upraised hands in his and s
descriptions.R: ut crying and they cried together, she sitting at his side. They could not yet speak to each other of the shame which she was bearing with him, or of the acts which had brought it down on them. His confession was silent, and her promise of faithfulness was silent. Open-minded as she was, she nevertheless shrank from the words which would have expressed their mutual consciousness, as she would have shrunk from flakes of fire. She could not say, How much is only slander and false suspicion? and he
descriptions.M: is not come yet? No. Are you going out again without taking tea, Caleb? said Mrs. Garth, seeing that her absent-minded husband was putting on again the hat which he had just taken off. No, no; I'm only going to Mary a minute. Mary was in a grassy corner of the garden, where there was a swing loftily hung between two pear-trees. She had a pink kerchief tied over her head, making a little poke to shade her eyes from the level sunbeams, while she was giving a glorious swing to Letty, who laughed an
descriptions.F: , I could talk it well over with him, and we could go into business and the nature of things. Oh, you dear good father! cried Mary, putting her hands round her father's neck, while he bent his head placidly, willing to be caressed. I wonder if any other girl thinks her father the best man in the world! Nonsense, child; you'll think your husband better. Impossible, said Mary, relapsing into her usual tone; husbands are an inferior class of men, who require keeping in order. When they were enterin
descriptions.MB: rouble. People glorify all sorts of bravery except the bravery they might show on behalf of their nearest neighbors. Dorothea's eyes had a moist brightness in them, and the changed tones of her voice roused her uncle, who began to listen. It is true that a woman may venture on some efforts of sympathy which would hardly succeed if we men undertook them, said Mr. Farebrother, almost converted by Dorothea's ardor. Surely, a woman is bound to be cautious and listen to those who know the world bette
descriptions.JC: ut of the room, and Mr. Brooke was nodding in a nap, she returned to the subject with renewed vivacity. Mr. Lydgate would understand that if his friends hear a calumny about him their first wish must be to justify him. What do we live for, if it is not to make life less difficult to each other? I cannot be indifferent to the troubles of a man who advised me in my trouble, and attended me in my illness. Dorothea's tone and manner were not more energetic than they had been when she was at the head
descriptions.LC: that Truberry had gone over to the other side entirely at the instigation of his wife, who had scented peerages in the air from the very first introduction of the Reform question, and would sign her soul away to take precedence of her younger sister, who had married a baronet. Lady Chettam thought that such conduct was very reprehensible, and remembered that Mrs. Truberry's mother was a Miss Walsingham of Melspring. Celia confessed it was nicer to be Lady than Mrs., and that Dodo never minded ab
descriptions.MrsV: pounds except that the loan had come from her uncle Bulstrode. Lydgate's odious humors and their neighbors' apparent avoidance of them had an unaccountable date for her in their relief from money difficulties. If the invitations had been accepted she would have gone to invite her mamma and the rest, whom she had seen nothing of for several days; and she now put on her bonnet to go and inquire what had become of them all, suddenly feeling as if there were a conspiracy to leave her in isolation wi
descriptions.MrV: t his side in mournful but unreproaching fellowship with shame and isolation. All this went on within her in a mere flash of time—while she sank into the chair, and raised her eyes to her brother, who stood over her. I know nothing, Walter. What is it? she said, faintly. He told her everything, very inartificially, in slow fragments, making her aware that the scandal went much beyond proof, especially as to the end of Raffles. People will talk, he said. Even if a man has been acquitted by a jury
descriptions.MrsCad: n able to hinder it, any more than I have. There's something singular in things: they come round, you know. It must be about Dodo, said Celia, who had been used to think of her sister as the dangerous part of the family machinery. She had seated herself on a low stool against her husband's knee. For God's sake let us hear what it is! said Sir James. Well, you know, Chettam, I couldn't help Casaubon's will: it was a sort of will to make things worse. Exactly, said Sir James, hastily. But what is
